ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to take ideas in my head and more easily draw them on paper
How to trust my drawing skills, both still life and imaginative and abstract skills as well.

thinking about space and time differently
letting go of a product and thinking about/valuing the process
being willing to fail, make a mess, do something weird
More appreciation for art.

This class was a fun intro to drawing! We learned how to make contour and gesture drawings, linear perspective, light and shadows, and other skills that allowed us to think more deeply about compositions and creating art that was personal for each of us.

I am pleasantly surprised with this class. I expected the class to be very technical based and more focused on teaching us skills and techniques, but I feel like I also learned a lot about my weaknesses and also what I enjoyed vs. what I found difficult to grasp for some of the sections. I have definitely come out with a more solid foundation of drawing and just what kind of things you can do with it and how it can be a way for me to express my thoughts or feelings. I initially only thought that good drawing meant a product that was perfect and looked really good but I learned that that's not necessarily the case.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Excellent course!

I believe this class was difficult over zoom during the pandemic, however, it became an extremely therapeutic and positive addition to my weeks, something I looked forward to during remote learning and I think it was handled to the best of everyone's ability.
I wish it had been in person but I appreciated getting to see everyone's work online

It's difficult to teach/learn drawing over zoom (I imagine it's easier to learn how to correct certain mistakes in person) but this class was still really great. I really appreciated the class environment where improvement and effort were valued over producing great work from the outset and where everyone was really supportive of each other. Also, building up drawing skills progressively was helpful towards putting them to use together at the end.

In the beginning I thought it would be really hard to do art classes over zoom, but I think it turned out better than I had expected. I liked how Prof Hysen showed us a few lecture slides to give us a feel for the next section that we were going into and then gave us time to draw on our own and try to learn it ourselves. The great thing about this course is that there is a lot of flexibility in our assignments because drawing is a very subjective thing, and there's really no right or wrong way to do something. It was a little hard to get individual feedback during class as the professor cannot just look over at our drawings, but hopefully that won't be the case in the fall, but I do think that having individual meetings did help in giving that feedback.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was difficult to have course themes for still life when not everyone was able to look at the same things
critiques were a fun way to see other people's work
Posting our work to the Google Drive was helpful because it allowed us to see everyone's work as best as we could during a virtual semester.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!!! Great class to learn skills while having fun.
yes! this is a great course and a wonderful time, its a great break away from the traditional type of course offered at yale
Yes I would l!
I think everyone should take an intro art class before graduating Yale, even sooner than graduating, in case you realize this is an undiscovered passion.
yesit was so fun, rewarding, rejuvenating, and expanding. I learned a lot and enjoyed the process.
Yes. Drawing is awesome.
Yes!! It's a great intro to drawing, a wonderful class environment and professor! Especially as a non-art major, this class was great in allowing me to explore a field outside my own.

Yes! I would definitely recommend taking it with Prof Hysen! She really wanted us to learn and get "the feel" for what we were drawing like actually trying to feel the shape of trees that we had to draw for homework. It was an interesting experience over zoom, but as the semester went on our class became much more comfortable with each other and really did some personal pieces for our final project with no fear of being judged which was pretty cool. I really enjoy art, so I found that the homework didn't really feel like hw but a really nice break from other classes! You do learn different techniques, but I think that the intellectual/philosophical discussions were what made the class more insightful.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: One in person class, but all through zoom
N/a
We had a virtual seminar with occasional periods of individual one-on-one meetings with the professor for help and feedback on our projects.
